Recently, I purchased a video game which was on sale that I had otherwise not planned on buying.  It was a welcome surprise; one which ended up making my day.  I work very hard and I often put in extended hours, and video games are a means by which I unwind and relax.  The sale was both an emotional and economic boon, and one which I am grateful for.

Recently, I had a chance to order food online from a vendor previously limited to a physical kiosk.  The food is some of my favorite, and the means to purchase my favorite food online provided a real mood boost.

Lastly, I had a chance to speak to a friend on the phone today; this friend lives far away, and we don't get a chance to talk much.  We recounted events from a party we went to some time ago, and the memory was a welcome change from the typical grind.

A friend of mine from college was visiting for a convention that I hadn't seen for 4 years.  When he had time between panels at the convention, I invited him and his brother to hang out for lunch.  They wanted to go to a ramen place, so I took them to one of the best places in town, and we had a great time.  Food was amazing.
Later in the afternoon, some other friends of mine came over to hang out, and watch some tv on netflix.  We also played a local multiplayer video game called Overcooked that was funny.

My college friend and his brother visiting from out of town wanted to get something to eat late at night before their flight the next morning.  So we picked them up at the convention center, and took them to one of the best all you can eat sushi places in town.  We gorged on green mussel, nigiri sushi, handrolls, specialty rolls and green tea ice cream.  While we were there, they got to meet my other friends and had a blast.  Hoping to early next year head out to visit him in California, and go on a brewery trip.

I strongly believe that ordinary yet priceless things such as health, family solidarity and closeness, important people like friends who will always be there for you no matter what and job satisfaction can definitely lead to happiness. I am opposed to the belief that money makes everyone happy and replete.

As I can remember, when I was younger I used to held parties at my home solely with my family and relatives. Especially on my birthdays, my mom cooked my favorite foods and made my favorite birthday cake with chocolate.

Although money and wealth are essential elements for human life as they help people cover their expenses, do things they want and purchase materials people want, I don't think that they are the determinant factors. Furthermore, self-contentment could be another important ingredient for us to be happy. We can be happy with however little we have only if we have the self-satisfaction and self-contentment.

Describe an event that made you happy." Happiness is an abstract concept. But its presence is visible and people become happy when they get something desirable, travel to someplace exciting, get some good news and celebrate joyful events. The cue card wants to know about an event that made you happy.

If you can talk about this cue card, you should be able to answer the following cue cards as well: 1. Describe a memorable event of your life. 2. Talk about an event that made you happy. 3. Describe a happy memory you have. 4.

I had a nice talk with my father. He was asking me about my plans for employment, and reassured me that if I do not want to teach, I don't have to. He expressed his concern that he still would be happy if I worked with kids because of all my hard work in college getting the degree I have, and I reassured him that I still have plenty of options. It was just nice to know he had my back.

I made it to Detroit, during rush hour, and didn't get in a car accident. I had never driven this route before and it was incredibly stressful because it was also raining. However, I got where I needed to go and let out a huge sigh of relief when I finally stepped out of my car.

I woke up and the day was already hot and I hadn't slept as well with the heat. My step son is waiting on me because he wants to go the DMV and get his state ID. This is a bit annoying because he needs a lot of hand-holding in getting this set up and he has high functioning autism. As much as I love my son, sometimes I need some time to get started, especially on a hot week with little sleep. While he and I were discussing the wait and expectations at the DMV, my roommate's daughter came over and hugged my leg. Normally, when I get up in the morning, I make a point to say good morning to her and hug her, but I had forgotten. She hadn't and decided to come over and do the hugging herself instead of do without. I bent down and hugged her and felt renewed that my time spent with children and bringing them up to adulthood was not wasted. It was a nice moment and helped me change my attitude and get us to the DMV.

I looked over last night and saw my partner had passed out on the couch and the dog passed out next to her. She had given up the dog to go to a home with her cousin last year because they were co-owners of the pet and the cousin had moved into his own house with his new wife. However, it's been a bumpy road and the dog has escaped and had a laundry list of bad behaviors in her new home. Because of that, the cousin brought her back to our house for 4th of July, assuming she'd be more comfortable and we could keep an eye on her. Instantly, she changed and immediately we realized she had missed being with us and being in our home. Specifically, she wanted to spend time with my step daughter and her mom. We ended up keeping her and now she sleeps next to my partner any time she can.

I was in the grocery store with my best friend. We were picking up a few things for a party we were going to later in the day. There was a lady in a motorized wheelchair shopping as well. While we went down the aisle I turned back to notice the lady struggling to try to stand because there was something on a high shelf she needed. I walked back and asked her if I could help. She was thankful for my help and told me "no one ever stops and helps anymore". I told her it was no big deal. My friend noticed and said something to me and again I said it was nothing. But later on, my friend remembered and told everyone at the party how kind I had been. Kind of embarrassing, but 2 other friends made a toast to me.

One thing that I was happy about was being able to watch Big Brother on time last night. I usually miss the show because I am busy and I have to play catch-up to watch the episodes (mind you, the show airs 3 times a week). So, when I finished showering and got ready for 8 PM, I was glad that I was able to get ready in time and watch the show without interruption.

Yesterday afternoon, I was able to clip the weeds in my mother's vegetable garden. Before Big Brother, I went outside and wished to tackle the tall weeds that had grown due to the days of rain we have experiences. I felt happy and relieved that I was able to make such great progress. I did about half the garden in about an hour despite the heat outside. I felt happy also because I was productive for the day.

One last thing that made me happy was seeing my niece today. She is 7 years old and she lives about 10 miles away from my parents and I's home. She came today after a long while. I hadn't seen her in about a month. Her father, my brother, dropped her off at my parents' house and we got to see her and catch up on her life.

I helped cut a kitchen counter. We made three different cuts. It was cut with a circular saw, and we had to make a guide each time we cut. It took a little while to finish, but we wanted to make sure a good done was done. I was happy because I like to learn how to do and partake in home improvement projects. I was happy that it was a success and that nothing went wrong.

I was in a small town in Colorado and it was a Sunday afternoon.  It turned out that it was one of the big events of the summer for this town and there were a lot of people gathered around the river.  I looked up at a restaurant overlooking the river and I said "Now that's the place to view the event, but it's probably booked for hours.  I went up to the desk and put our name on the list and after 15 minutes the hostess called us and took us to nearly the exact place I had pointed out.  The table was, in fact, better than what I thought it would be and we could watch the entire event while we had our lunch.

I was searching for a good camping spot around Crested Butte and I found one that was very near to town.  It was up a dirt road but not too bad.  It was crowded when we got there and the sign said "full".  On a whim, I decided to ask the camp host if there were any cancellations and he said "as a matter of fact, somebody just left a spot early".  He showed us to the spot and it was right on the river.  We camped for two nights in one of the best camping spots I ever had, with the river lulling us to sleep each night.

Life is full of unexpected surprises. There are many opportunities when one can secretly wish for something exciting to happen  something out of the ordinary. The real surprise is when the wish unexpectedly comes true. I never believed that something like this could ever happen to me; such a thing that would make me stop and look back at the events in awe. I think you would agree that something as simple as being lost in the forest for less than ten minutes should have no influence on my life. If you do agree, that makes both of us wrong.Throughout my childhood, I loved the wild. My family and I would always go for a walk in the downtown forest of Cootes Paradise. There were many times I thought of what could happen if we were to lose our way from the trail and have to live off of the land until we found our way back to civilization. I thought it would be the greatest experience ever.

I can remember many happy events of my life and out of those, I would like to talk about the event that I can still remember vividly regarding my success in the board exam. The moment I heard that I had been awarded a scholarship based on my performance in the board exam, I became the happiest man in the world. This was indeed a very happy moment for me as it is something I was looking forward to achieving and the news made my parents quite happy and proud.I spent almost a month with great anxiety regarding my result publication. I started speculating so many things and many of them were negative. I could hardly keep away the tensions about my upcoming result. The result was so important that my college admission would mostly depend on it. I could not sleep well in the night before the result publishing. I think this is a common anxiety for students and I was familiar with this type of anxiety. However, this particular exam results game me more nightmares than any other time of my life.

Describe a happy event of your life" is an example of cue card topic that gives a candidate a wide range of options to pick from. You are virtually free to talk about any event that you think you would be flexible to talk about. On the contrary, the topic like "Describe a famous writer in your country" narrows your option. You can't just pick any writer and start talking about him. For the later topic, you need to think about such a writer and give some factual information about him.The cue cards that give you wide options are usually easier to talk about since you won't have to wonder a lot to pick what you would talk about. For this cue card i.e. "Describe a happy event of your life" think about an event in your life that made you happy. If you take it from your life rather than making it up, you would be able to give more details and extend the topic.

The problem: A common answer to this question is to compliment the company by saying something like, XYZ is the leading creator of innovative solutions, and I want to work for a market leader, says Matt Doucette, director of global talent acquisition for the job website Monster.com. A more honest answer, he adds, might be, You were the only ones who read my resume, so of course I want to work for you. I need a job.What you should say: A good answer, however, revolves around the mission, vision, and values of the company. If they are a match for your goals and desires, then talk about that, he says. Talk about being connected to the values of the company. Talk about how the mission speaks to you, and then tie those things back to the description and your unique skill set.

The key component to effective savoring is focused attention. By taking the time and spending the effort to appreciate the positive, people are able to experience more well-being.

One group was told to focus on all the upbeat things they could find sunshine, flowers, smiling pedestrians. Another was to look for negative stuff graffiti, litter, frowning faces. The third group was instructed to walk just for the exercise. At the end of the week, when the walkers well-being was tested again, those who had deliberately targeted positive cues were happier than before the experiment. The negatively focused subjects were less happy, and the just plain exercisers scored in between. The point, says Bryant, is that you see what you look for. And you can train yourself to attend to the joy out there waiting to be had, instead of passively waiting for it to come to you.

In one set of studies, depressed participants were invited to take a few minutes once a day to relish something that they usually hurry through (e.g., eating a meal, taking a shower, finishing the workday, or walking to the subway). When it was over, they were instructed to write down in what ways they had experienced the event differently as well as how that felt compared with the times when they rushed through it. In another study, healthy students and community members were instructed to savor two pleasurable experiences per day, by reflecting on each for two or three minutes and trying to make the pleasure last as long and as intensely as possible. In all these studies those participants prompted to practice savoring regularly showed significant increases in happiness and reductions in depression.

My dog had been feeling sick in May, she did not have any energy and was not eating her food. She is still young, so for her to have such a sudden change in behavior was alarming. I took her to the doctor and after extensive testing, they found that she had a liver infection. This sounded bad to me, but they assured me that with medication and proper diet, she would be okay. I was diligent about making sure she took her pills and was eating healthy, and she got better. It took about a month, but my happy dog is back, and nothing could make me happier then having her back to normal and healthy!

I strongly believe that ordinary yet priceless things such as health, family solidarity and closeness, important people like friends who will always be there for you no matter what and job satisfaction can definitely lead to happiness. I am opposed to the belief that money makes everyone happy and replete. Although money and wealth are essential elements for human life as they help people cover their expenses, do things they want and purchase materials people want, I don't think that they are the determinant factors. Furthermore, self-contentment could be another important ingredient for us to be happy. We can be happy with however little we have only if we have the self-satisfaction and self-contentment.

A month ago I found a great number (like 30) of caterpillars eating my parsley in my garden. After researching I discovered they were Eastern Swallowtail. I moved them to the porch and covered them with a mosquito net for protection from predators. I added sticks from the yard for them to crawl up and pupate on when they were ready. I provided them food after they ate all the parsley. It made me extremely happy to watch them grow and get bigger, pupate, and now they are all hatching into beautiful butterflies. They are bringing me a lot of happiness.

I was on the 25 Treasure Island on Treasure Island . Two tourists that didn't speak/understand English well wanted to get to the part of the Bay Bridge where there's a walking/biking path (the East Span from Yerba Buena Island to Oakland). The 25 goes only on the West Span (Treasure Island/SF), doesn't have a stop on Yerba Buena Island, and Treasure Island is under construction so the bus stops can be confusing. They tried asked a couple of different people on the bus but they weren't able to help or didn't want to help. Luckily, for the tourists a guy stepped up and helped them. He explained to them how they needed to get off the last stop on the island and where they have to walk to get to Yerba Buena. When the bus approached the last stop and it was apparent that the tourists were still confused, he got off the bus with them. (At that time of day, the 25 is scheduled to run is every 20 minutes but it's often delayed. The 25 is also the only public transportation option between Treasure Island and SF.)Living in a city that has a high population of visible homelessness, it's easy to get jaded. Brushing people off is normal. It was heartwarming to see someone help others out. He didn't have to get off the bus with them. I'd like to think that when those tourists go back home they'll tell their family and friends about the nice guy instead of the all the people begging and sleeping on the streets.

I was once shopping for a gift for a friend's birthday. I had set my budget, and I told myself I would only spend money on my friend's gift. Well, once I made it to the store, the most beautiful scent wafted past me from the perfume counter. The salesgirl had sprayed it for another customer. I told myself I didn't need another perfume and just go buy my friend's gift and leave. I purchased a beautiful silk scarf for my friend. I can remember many happy events of my life and out of those, I would like to talk about the event that I can still remember vividly regarding my success in the board exam. The moment I heard that I had been awarded a scholarship based on my performance in the board exam, I became the happiest man in the world. This was indeed a very happy moment for me as it is something I was looking forward to achieving and the news made my parents quite happy and proud.I spent almost a month with great anxiety regarding my result publication. I started speculating so many things and many of them were negative. I could hardly keep away the tensions about my upcoming result. The result was so important that my college admission would mostly depend on it. I could not sleep well in the night before the result publishing. I think this is a common anxiety for students and I was familiar with this type of anxiety. However, this particular exam results game me more nightmares than any other time of my life.The result was published at around 11.00 am and I found that I did exceptionally well. I was so relieved and happy that I literally shouted. Then I hurriedly came back to our home and gave the news to my parents. They were happy too. My father bought sweets and my mother gave it to our neighbours. I felt excited, happy and relieved. At that time I was about 15 years old.

"Describe a happy event of your life" is an example of cue card topic that gives a candidate a wide range of options to pick from. You are virtually free to talk about any event that you think you would be flexible to talk about. On the contrary, the topic like "Describe a famous writer in your country" narrows your option. You can't just pick any writer and start talking about him. For the later topic, you need to think about such a writer and give some factual information about him.

Make your own happiness a priority.Your happiness matters. We tend to put other people's happiness before our own and make excuses for the reasons why we neglect our needs - we are too busy, too skint, too stressed out. If you don't value your own happiness then no one else will. It is entirely possible to look out for your own needs and still care about your friends and family. If you are happy, you are more likely to spread happiness and care for those around you.Think about what makes you happy. Now what would make me delirious would be to wake late, eat cake, drink wine and spend the day sunbathing somewhere on a hot and beautiful beach. That's not realistic at this point in my life as I think my kids would have something to say about it!But what does make me happy is writing, fresh linen, watching a good film, open fires, sauvignon blanc, walking in the woods with the dog, my chickens, a good meal with awesome friends, a lie in with my husband, dancing...There are a LOT of things that make me happy that cost little or nothing and those things I make time for. It's easy to neglect your own desires but so important that you don't.2. Spend time with people who make you happyWho are the people that you enjoy spending time with? Who makes you happy, who loves, respects and appreciates you and who makes you want to be a better person? If you surround yourself with negative people then your life will be filled with negativity, and the opposite is true also, being around positive, happy people make you aspire to be positive and happy.Sometimes we can't help whom we have to spend time with, we may have work colleagues or family members who are Debbie Downers and we have to hang out with them at times. But in our social lives it is so important to keep awesome and positive people around us, the ones who make us laugh, who are joyous to be around. Some of the people who make me happy are filthy minded, raucous and quite dark! But they are interesting and make me feel good about myself.3. Take responsibility for your own lifeThis is a biggy for me, the trait I hate the most in people is refusing to take responsibility for their own lives. People who have constant excuses for their bad behaviour, who think it is always someone or something else's fault. People who say "its alright for you because..."Own your life. Own your mistakes. Live, learn and move on. The world doesn't owe you anything; you make your own path through this world. Everyone faces hardships throughout their life and you can choose to be a martyr to your tough times or own the shit out of them and move forward as a stronger person.4. Be yourself. Everyone else is takenBe the best version of yourself that you can be. Be true to yourself and be proud of the person you are. It's easy to compare ourselves to others, and the fact is, there will always be someone thinner, smarter and prettier - but honestly, who cares?Whatever part of yourself you admire the most, be *that* more. The parts you dislike about yourself, be *that* less. Be proud of your quirks and weirdness, stand tall and proud and applaud your inner awesomeness!5. Create your own happinessNo one can change your life and make you truly happy except you. Choose positivity over negativity and smile because you can. Choose to be happy with who you are right now and allow your joy to shape your present and your future. Do the things that make you happy more often, spend time with those who bring out your smile and create your own happiness.If you are waiting for someone else to make you happy, you may be waiting a long time.6. Find the silver liningWhen you are going through a tough time it is easy to slip into feeling defeated and that life is just too hard. We go through things in life that we think will break us. Illness, bereavement, job loss, money troubles, and it can feel like there is no way to get through these times. The truth is we are stronger than we think.It is important to look for the silver lining even if that is only the tiniest sliver of hope. If there is no silver lining in your situation, for example the death of a loved one, then try to count your blessings and be grateful of the good things in your life.When things are hard, and you feel down, take a few deep breaths and remind yourself that you can and will grow stronger from these hard times. Remain conscious of your blessings and victories, of all the things in your life that are right. Focus on what you have, not on what you havent.7. Be kindBe a kind person, one who is caring and thoughtful, who thinks of others and treats people with respect. Kindness breeds kindness. Its a simple one but so important.8. Be openBe open; share your thoughts and feelings with the people closest to you. If you are hurting then accept the hurt and allow yourself time to heal, let your loved ones in and be honest with them. A problem shared is a problem halved, the act of speaking your troubles out loud can be of as much help as any advice you may receive. Becoming a more open person can lead to real happiness.9. Let go of the pastOur pasts define who we are and we can learn lessons from the things we have gone through, but when your past is keeping you from moving forward it becomes a problem. We have all had tough experiences but if you are reliving the pain of this experience again and again and it is affecting your present then it is time to let go.Letting go doesn't mean forgetting what has happened or pretending it didn't happen, it means letting go of the pain and resentment that is holding you back. This is easier in some situations than others, but be honest with yourself and if something from your past is affecting your present then it may be time to talk through those issues either with a trusted friend or family member or a trained therapist.10. Take a chanceTwo years ago my husband and I took a leap of faith, we sold our home and rented a 15th century mill to push our photography business forward. It was a risk, but a calculated risk. I knew that if there was a motto to live by (other than 'If you can't sing well, sing LOUD') it was 'I'd rather regret the things I did, than the things I didn't do.' We plotted and planned, did the sums a million times and then decided to take a chance. And it was the best thing we ever did, don't get me wrong there have been some very tough times but I knew we had made the right decision.Life is not about getting a chance; it is about taking a chance. If there is something you have always dreamed of doing, then try to make it happen. If it works you will have achieved a goal, if it doesn't you know you at least tried it and you WILL learn a lesson from it.11. Be mindfulLive in the present, in the here and now. It is so easy to let busy lives, technology and procrastination take over our lives, but being mindful of the things around you can bring peace and happiness into your life. Take time to notice the things that are important in your life right now, experience life as it happens. Don't dwell on the past or imagine how great things could be in the future. This moment is the only thing guaranteed to you in life, we never know what the future holds so enjoy today.12. Concentrate on the things you can control, not the things you can'tWorry and stress is a normal part of life but when your day is taken up with worrying about the things in life you cannot control it is a sign that things need to change. Worrying about things that are beyond your control is such a waste of your time and emotional energy.Worry affects you, not the person or situation you are worrying about. If it is important to you and you can control the outcome and positively help a problem then great, if not then let it go. You have enough genuine problems to face in life without upsetting yourself with things beyond your control.13. Face your problems and make a positive changeThere's no point in burying your head in the sand, if you have a problem, you need to face it head on and make a positive change as no one is going to do it for you. The problem will not just disappear on it's own without action from you and no problem is too big to overcome. It takes acceptance from you and then a plan, no matter how small the steps, you need to do little and often and move it forward.Some problems you will be able to overcome alone with a good old-fashioned list and a bit of hard work. Others are bigger and need support from others. There is no shame in asking for help, whether it is the help of friends, family or a professional.14. Appreciate the things you havePerspective. There will always be someone better off than you and someone worse off than you. Learn to appreciate the things you have, rather than worrying about the things you don't. I'm not saying we shouldn't aspire to be greater than we are now, but don't be so busy in thinking of the things that you don't have that you forget to appreciate all you do.15. Love those around youAppreciate and love those around you, bring joy to the people who mean the most by telling them how much they mean to you. Since my sister moved to Australia I end all our conversations with "love you" I didn't do this before she left but her moving half way around the world brought out something in me that makes me want her to know how much she means to me.This isn't about huge grand gestures, it is about personal, meaningful acts that let your friends and family know how awesome they are. A text message, sending a photo that you think they'll find funny, a hug, a few words.
A smile never cost anybody anything and a day seems to go better when you are surrounded by colleagues that smile and are willing to help you anytime or just to hug you when you are not feeling ok.

Though it's not today, This incident which happened to me few weeks before, is the happiest thing that I have got in a while!!It was a normal day at Branch, being a branch with lesser footfall there was hardly any customers came that day to have an interaction to make my day interesting.At around 12 , I got a parcel when I opened it, it made my day and has become the happiest and sweetest thing I got in a while.

As I remember when I was studying in 8th-9th standard I was very average student or let's say weak student. To be honest I failed many exams even I scored zero in languages.My mother was scolded by every teacher and putting a blame on parent was something very easy and was practiced by them. I Remember once my class teacher scolded my mother badly because again I was failed in Marathi paper. At that time I really felt very bad and that was something which got stuck and still I can remember each and every word said by teacher to my mom.I don't know why, but from that day I promised myself that my mother will not go with same situation again. And I improved. Every teacher appreciated my improvement.So here is the most memorable day of my life. 10th result got out, I was ranked at 4th position amongst the five rankers.And luckily I got the same teacher felicitating the top five rankers and this time neither she uttered a word nor me.My mom was watching felicitation programme proudly.And that day I promised again that I'll keep this proudness going.

This week, I was asked to work from a different office (to support Operations directly during production release), which is lot closer compared to my actual work location. Naturally, I jumped at the offer.The first day, I walked into the building and got myself introduced at the reception. She was an old Malay lady who seemed very friendly and helped me get through the door.Everyday my walk in and out of the office, she had to man the door and I was a little embarrassed to ask her every time I pass. She, however seemed not to mind my interruption in her daily routine. Today was my last day at this office and while I was coming back from my evening walk, I got the Security lady a juice along with my usual fruit snack. I thought I'd thank her for being patient enough to bear me this whole week.Though it wasn't a huge gesture she received it with so much humility and thanked me profusely for thinking about her.Her happy face made my evening a lot brighter. I think we all need a little appreciation/encouragement to lead this sometimes monotonous life.

This is the most basic and attractive sentiment you can express to another human beingthat simply being in the persons presence creates a positive feeling. Whether youre telling an employee that you need his skills, that you value his opinions, or just that you think hes good company, youve begun an interaction on a very high note

Take the previous remark a step further. This is the opposite of most relationship advicethat you should never take a specific negative action and suggest that its indicative of someones entire way of acting. Well, turn that on its head, by expressing that its not just this interaction that has produced positive feelings but basically all interactions with this person. Its an amazingly gratifying thing to hear.

Surprise someone by bringing up a positive thing that she did in the past, and youre almost guaranteed to induce a positive response. Maybe its a joke the person told that youre still laughing about; maybe its a small act of heroism she performed. Regardless, if its something she thought was long forgotten, learning that something she did made a positive, lasting impression on someone else is an amazing experience.

"Describe a happy event of your life" is an example of cue card topic that gives a candidate a wide range of options to pick from. You are virtually free to talk about any event that you think you would be flexible to talk about. On the contrary, the topic like "Describe a famous writer in your country" narrows your option. You can't just pick any writer and start talking about him. For the later topic, you need to think about such a writer and give some factual information about him.The cue cards that give you wide options are usually easier to talk about since you won't have to wonder a lot to pick what you would talk about. For this cue card i.e. "Describe a happy event of your life" think about an event in your life that made you happy. If you take it from your life rather than making it up, you would be able to give more details and extend the topic.

After few minutes we reached the fair and then collected the tickets. We were thoroughly enjoying everything we did that time. We entered the fair and took a deep breath to ease ourselves. We were kind of overwhelmed to observe the vast area with hundreds of shops and stalls. People were all around us and we felt like somehow we have come to a fairy land. Wherever we went, I was feeling so excited, everything was totally new to me as a grown-up lady. We took lots of photos from different views, purchased few interesting things within our limited budget and roamed in the whole area of the fair. I forgot my usual area, boundaries and the same thing I do almost every day and felt a happiness that I missed for a long. We spent almost 4-5 hours in the trade fair and at last returned to our home in the evening. We returned home by bus and I was so happy that I felt like discovering a new continent.

Five years on an island where oil paint just refuses to dry makes I quickly stop painting with it. I was stuck using acrylic paint (which I really dont like - its blending properties are terrible), learning to use charcoal and oil pastels (which was good for me too). When we settled into our new house one of the first things I did was paint with my beloved oils again. I cant describe how happy swirling the gooey paint seamlessly around on a canvas made me.

My wife and I were stuck in traffic, crawling along at less than 5 MPH. I saw a speed limit sign for 35 MPH, and made a joke about her having to make sure she stays under that speed. She laughed, which made me happy.

When we think about our lives, we generally expect that it's the big events that will bring us the most joy later on--remembering that amazing trip to Tahiti, say, or that huge work success.

the result of my SSC exam had been published. SSC is an educational level in our country which is equivalent to O Levels in English Medium.I was supposed to give this exam three years ago. Unfortunately, I couldn't give it due to accidental cause.These three years had been long and full of despair. Many times I felt like all the hopes had vanished. When my physical condition would get worse, there was no end of hopelessness. And, I couldn't help but feel a little burden to my family.But when the result had been published, everyone was so happy, for me. The result was surprisingly very good. I have never seen them feeling so proud of me.I felt like my hopeless days have finally come to an end. And, I finally achieved something that made my closed ones happy.It's the one happy event that happened in the past week.

My parents celebrate a wedding anniversary, its not just a celebration of their love and marriage. Its also a testament to the strong foundation they created for their children and families. Theyve worked hard over the years to provide for you and your siblings, so its even more important to show your appreciation for them on a day as special as an anniversary. Wishing your parents a happy anniversary is more than just a simple statement; its a way for you to express your gratitude and joy for being a part of their lives. Show your parents how much you care with these sentimental and celebratory anniversary quotes.

"Describe a happy event of your life" is an example of cue card topic that gives a candidate a wide range of options to pick from. You are virtually free to talk about any event that you think you would be flexible to talk about. On the contrary, the topic like "Describe a famous writer in your country" narrows your option. You can't just pick any writer and start talking about him. For the later topic, you need to think about such a writer and give some factual information about him.The cue cards that give you wide options are usually easier to talk about since you won't have to wonder a lot to pick what you would talk about. For this cue card i.e. "Describe a happy event of your life" think about an event in your life that made you happy. If you take it from your life rather than making it up, you would be able to give more details and extend the topic.Following are some of the ideas you can take as examples of happy events of your life but always try to speak about a real event of your life.1. Your father got promoted and your family celebrated it.2. You got admitted to a school/ college/ university where you dreamed of studying.3. The birth of your younger sister/ brother/ nephew/ niece or even your own kid if you are a father/ mother.4. One of your family members was severely ill but got healed miraculously.5. You won a competition.6. You did something for others and people acclaimed that.7. You got a scholarship.8. You overcame one of your obstacles.9. You went to visit a foreign country10. You achieved something noteworthy.11. You saved someone from a big problem. Cue Card Answer 2:In my face, I feel a glow whenever I remember the day I went to the International trade fair with some of my friends. That was my first International trade fair visit and this was such a happy experience that I still feel a great joy reciting the memory of this event. It was January 1998 and that time I was in my first year of college.Until I finished my college, I was kind of a newborn lady, who had never visited any places without her places of her local area. After I got admitted into the college, I started exploring the world and the amazing things that invite people like us. One day I planned with my friends that we would visit International trade fair. This might seem like a very usual and banal event for others but to me, that was a really exciting thing to do. Later on, we did as we thought and finalised our visit to the fair. After break period at college, we escaped by the back door (As a side note, I would like to mention that Id no previous record of escaping school or college before). We were five in members and we hired a taxi to reach the trade fair. There wasnt enough space to sit on the back side of the taxi and the taxi driver gave a suspicious look at us. Thats why with a fishy smile we took the decision that one of us would sit in front of the baby taxi with the taxi driver. It was a funny decision but there was no alternative to us and we enjoyed it. After few minutes we reached the fair and then collected the tickets. We were thoroughly enjoying everything we did that time. We entered the fair and took a deep breath to ease ourselves. We were kind of overwhelmed to observe the vast area with hundreds of shops and stalls. People were all around us and we felt like somehow we have come to a fairy land. Wherever we went, I was feeling so excited, everything was totally new to me as a grown-up lady. We took lots of photos from different views, purchased few interesting things within our limited budget and roamed in the whole area of the fair. I forgot my usual area, boundaries and the same thing I do almost every day and felt a happiness that I missed for a long. We spent almost 4-5 hours in the trade fair and at last returned to our home in the evening. We returned home by bus and I was so happy that I felt like discovering a new continent

Q. What do you think is important in achieving happiness?Answer: I strongly believe that ordinary yet priceless things such as health, family solidarity and closeness, important people like friends who will always be there for you no matter what and job satisfaction can definitely lead to happiness. I am opposed to the belief that money makes everyone happy and replete. Although money and wealth are essential elements for human life as they help people cover their expenses, do things they want and purchase materials people want, I don't think that they are the determinant factors. Furthermore, self-contentment could be another important ingredient for us to be happy. We can be happy with however little we have only if we have the self-satisfaction and self-contentment.Q. How do you celebrate some happy events?Answer: As I can remember, when I was younger I used to held parties at my home solely with my family and relatives. Especially on my birthdays, my mom cooked my favourite foods and made my favourite birthday cake with chocolate. Now that I am not a teenager anymore, I go out with my friends and in some special circumstances with my family as well. For example, on my graduation day, I went to a Greek restaurant with my parents, brother and my five best friends and we had a really great time. Generally speaking, I would say that I am more of an introvert person, so I totally prefer to spend substantial time with few friends rather than having many people and typical relationships. My happy moments and celebrations are also related to my friends and family members. Q. What role the camera and video play in celebrating?Answer: I would argue that these two tools, camera and video, play an integral part in different types of celebrations. First of all, most people have moments of their childhood and memories from childhood are captured in cameras. To illustrate, some of the most important events such as birthday parties, weddings, graduations and so on are included in these jigs and in this way the moment is captured and saved for a long period of time. Furthermore, as some essential and happy events are recorded, they could be used and displayed years later in order for some people to remember some significant events. A good illustration in my case is that on my 22nd birthday, my friends made me a really emotional video from all the years that we have been friends. Without the usage of the camera and video-recorder, this could never have happened.[Part-three question answers are written by Mary, UK] If you can talk about this cue card, you should be able to answer the following cue cards as well:1. Describe a memorable event of your life.2. Talk about an event that made you happy.3. Describe a happy memory you have.4. Describe a success you achieved in your life.

I can remember many happy events of my life and out of those, I would like to talk about the event that I can still remember vividly regarding my success in the board exam. The moment I heard that I had been awarded a scholarship based on my performance in the board exam, I became the happiest man in the world. This was indeed a very happy moment for me as it is something I was looking forward to achieving and the news made my parents quite happy and proud.I spent almost a month with great anxiety regarding my result publication. I started speculating so many things and many of them were negative. I could hardly keep away the tensions about my upcoming result. The result was so important that my college admission would mostly depend on it. I could not sleep well in the night before the result publishing. I think this is a common anxiety for students and I was familiar with this type of anxiety. However, this particular exam results game me more nightmares than any other time of my life.

Bronze medalists are happier than silver medalists. Why? They feel grateful to get a medal at all.Every night before you go to bed write three good things that happened to you that day. Jotting those down is pretty much all it takes to get a boost in well-being over time.Theres a second lesson here: the reverse is also true. Keeping track of the bad things will make you miserable. A convenient memory is a powerful thing. Do not train your brain to see the negative, teach it to see the positive.Try a gratitude visit. Write someone a letter thanking them and telling them how much what they have done for you means. Visit them and read it in person. Its a proven happiness WMD. More info here.

Cordiality is step one; frankly it's about as far as a lot of people get. Think of how many times you've been at a networking event or in a social situation where you and another person can't keep the conversation going past "hello."We live in an informal world for the most part, but trust me on this one. If someone has earned a degree or a position with a title, they've put a lot of their life's effort into achieving and perfecting it. So address them by it, at least once in your conversation. Even if they respond with, "No, please, call me Bill," they'll appreciate it.Or any phrase through which you're subtly suggesting that you'd like to do a small favor for someone

Yesterday was the Feast of the Transfiguration within Christianity. My husband and I are Eastern Catholics, and in our church, we have a tradition of bringing fruit to the church to be blessed. During the afternoon, in spite of a blistering heat wave, I drove to a nearby grocery store and spent a happy hour in the air conditioned store, browsing through the produce department, selecting the best grapes, apples, bananas, cherries, and other types of fruits to take with us that evening. They weren't all to be just for us two, but to be shared with others in our congregation. I was happy because I enjoy shopping for other people and rarely get that opportunity.

This morning, the weather report predicted our current heat wave would only get worse as the week went on. I had been inside for a couple of days, other than church and the store last night, and felt a bit restless. So this morning, I got up a little earlier than usual, right at sunrise when it wasn't quite so hot, and went for a walk around the neighborhood. I enjoyed ambling along the street, smiling and greeting other early risers out for the same reason. On the way back, I stopped at Starbucks and got a small cup of coffee to take home with me.

This afternoon, the heat wave was upon us with a vengeance. I'd done my walk in the morning, we'd been to church last night, and although I work from home, there wasn't a whole lot of work to do today. I felt a bit stir-crazy, so decided perhaps this was a day meant for relaxing. I decided to treat myself to an afternoon of "binge-watching" and selected "Downton Abbey," a show I hadn't seen for some time. As the stately theme music rose in my headphones, I felt really happy, because I don't watch much TV during the day so this was a rare treat.

Sometimes people come into your life and you know right away that they were meant to be there, to serve some sort of purpose, teach you a lesson, or to help you figure out who you are or who you want to become. You never know who these people may be (possibly your roommate, neighbor, coworker, longlost friend, lover, or even a complete stranger) but when you lock eyes with them, you know at that very moment that they will affect your life in some profound way.

The first day of school our professor introduced himself and challenged us to get to know someone we didnt already know.I stood up to look around when a gentle hand touched my shoulder. I turned around to find a wrinkled, little old lady beaming up at mewith a smile that lit up her entire being.She said, Hi handsome. My name is Rose. Im eighty-seven years old. Can I give you a hug?I laughed and enthusiastically responded, Of course you may! and she gave me a giant squeeze.Why are you in college at such a young, innocent age? I asked.She jokingly replied, Im here to meet a rich husband, get married, and have a couple of kidsNo seriously, I asked. I was curious what may have motivated her to be taking on this challenge at her age.

Our picnic has ended well. Through this visit, we better understand the lives of our Vietnamese people. Not only that, the trip also makes us happy and happy to prepare for next week. We thanked the Vinschool Board of Management and the teachers for providing us with an exciting and rewarding field trip. We have learned many new things and have had wonderful moments with our teachers. and you. Hope we have a chance to come here again.

End of the game, everyone rest, lunch and luggage preparing to return to Hanoi.It's time to say goodbye to Dam Long; The trip closed with a lot of fun, not just for me but for everyone. Being close to nature helps us to discover more interesting things and to understand the necessity of protecting the environment. The trip will be an unforgettable memory of the students that after each time we look back, we can smile, remember about the innocent months of school year under the beloved Bac Ha.

It is important to say I am 23yrs of age as of today, add afew months or days however best you see fit.I have experienced most things a typical African kid has, especially Kenyan kid.Kenya is in Africa, please don't ask me if Africa is a country. It is a Damn Continent.Back to what I was saying, I have gone through what any typical Kenyan kid has experienced.So what are the top five life events that made me happyNote, I am an extremely selfish being and thus do not expect any to relate to anyone apart from me, myself and I.

I was young and naive, 612yrs of age. Owning a bicycle was what earned you the cool kid in my block. I had pestered and nagged my dad abt buying me a bicycle. Mind you we were and still are a middle class family and any resources within the family were of great value towards surviving, so requests or items of pleasure were greatfly frowned and looked down in our 5-member family. But this did not discourage me, being the first born I thought, it might atleast earn me the rights to request for a bicycle from Dad. He however proved me wrong once I bluttered out the damn word, explaining how he had my two sisters to look after, how bills had been piling up and every hardship on earth was upon his shoulders. Being 12 saved me from reasoning and fueled my persistence. Dad asked me to top in my calss and he would buy me my item of demand, which if you recall was a good mountain, 21-gear bicycle with a head-lamp and a rear laguage carrier. Little did he know that he had poured fuel onto my burning desire to won a bicycle than I had topped my next end of term exams. And as a favour did him the pleasure of topping my entire stream of 100 student. KABOOM! Next Morning, my bicycle, not exactly what I had requested but apart from it being a ladys bicycle model, it had all the gear levels I wanted and moved. Being a kid, I cared less of my requirements so long as the were atleat half met, and to my knowledge, back then, they had been met. Talk about being the cool kid, bragging rights reserved for my entire primary education

I received monumental news from my acupuncture clinic today. I am a long time patient who also experienced an amazing recovery from hip replacement, so much so that I published a resource guide about the experience. The editor of the clinic newsletter knew my story and has agreed to insert an article in the October edition discussing a free electronic giveaway that month. The one-sided dialogue went on for so long that others stopped to watch, dogs stopped to watch, and we had a good laugh as I continued to receive what sounded like a bit of a scolding.

Having an afternoon to myself on August 06 made me very happy!  While traveling with my husband, he had a work appointment all afternoon, and I stayed at the hotel by myself for almost five hours. All of a sudden two tour buses drove up and dropped off lots of Chicago Cubs fans.  I was wearing a St Louis Cardinals shirt, so found plenty of people who wanted to talk with me!  My afternoon was very pleasant and made me happy.

I had three (3) events yesterday that influenced my happiness.  First, I learned that my credit score had increased which means that everything that I have been doing to improve it over the past year has increased it and made room for new opportunity financially. Next, yesterday morning I got a call from a representative at a car dealership saying his manager invited me in to purchase a vehicle. I was in awe that just as I learned the score had increased I would get such a call.  You see, my previous vehicle broke down on me roughly five (5) times in the past week or so.  I took him up on that invitation, but then I had to find a way to get to the dealership.  The person I asked said yes and then failed me by intentionally not answering the phone.  However, God sent me an angel in another friend who was more than willing to take me there. He even did a bit of shopping himself.  Finally, the icing on the cake was the joy in knowing that I was actually approved for an auto loan on a brand new late model vehicle. Yes!  Happiness was all mine yesterday.

Need some positive thinking? How about some books that make you happyWhile the idea of a book making you happy is obviously a stretch, peace of mind is often a product of a simple cognitive pattern: you see what you think about, and you think about what you see. Happy in, happy out.This is difficult when wisdom, empathy, love, and happiness are drowned out by a news cycle bent on spectacle. These days the news is hard to escape  between social media, television, radio, and well-meaning friends and colleagues, we are inundated with whats going on in the outside world.that have happy event in past 24 hours.

While a working knowledge of current events is important, all too often were immersed in the 24-hour news cycle and when negativity abounds, our mental health and sense of well-being begin to erode.Short of going all Henry Thoreau and retreating to the woods for awhile, what can we do to lift our spirits, find an escape, and change the things we think about? The first and most obvious step is to abstain from social media, but thats not entirely effective  or even possible, in many cases. A second possibility is to fill our brains with good stuff; to seek out positivity and nourish our souls with that instead.The following list contains both fiction and non-fiction happy bookseverything from self-help to humor but what these books share in common is their ability to inspire happiness in lost 24 hours.

Hector and the Search for Happiness by Francois  Hector travels from Paris to China to Africa to the United States, and along the way he keeps a list of observations about the people he meets. Combining the winsome appeal of The Little Prince with the inspiring philosophy of The Alchemist, Hectors journey around the world and into the human soul is entertaining, empowering, and smile-inducingas winning in its optimism as it is wise in its simplicity.

My sister recently had a baby and I have been putting off going to visit him for a while now since I think he's too fragile for me to handle and would prefer to at least keep my distance. So I visited her just to see how she was doing and like 4 minutes in she asks me if I wanted to hold him. I tell her no and she insists and makes me sit and places him in my arms showing me the best way to hold him properly. I was stiff and awkward but the little guy was unbothered by my stiff grip on him and as I got more used to holding him I began to talk to him a little. Not in the baby voice kind of way but just random stuff. While I spoke his mouth would twitch and he almost looked like he was smiling, like he understood what I was saying and I know it was stupid to think that but for some reason it made me cry. It was all happy tears because I felt pretty good for my first time interacting with him.

I can remember many happy events of my life and out of those, I would like to talk about the event that I can still remember vividly regarding my success in the board exam. The moment I heard that I had been awarded a scholarship based on my performance in the board exam, I became the happiest man in the world. This was indeed a very happy moment for me as it is something I was looking forward to achieving and the news made my parents quite happy and proud.I spent almost a month with great anxiety regarding my result publication. I started speculating so many things and many of them were negative. I could hardly keep away the tensions about my upcoming result. The result was so important that my college admission would mostly depend on it. I could not sleep well in the night before the result publishing. I think this is a common anxiety for students and I was familiar with this type of anxiety. However, this particular exam results game me more nightmares than any other time of my life.The result was published at around 11.00 am and I found that I did exceptionally well. I was so relieved and happy that I literally shouted. Then I hurriedly came back to our home and gave the news to my parents. They were happy too. My father bought sweets and my mother gave it to our neighbours. I felt excited, happy and relieved. At that time I was about 15 years old. It happened in our hometown called (... say the name of your hometown...)

There's an easy-to-articulate, hard-to-implement best practice when it comes to how to teach yourself to be happy. It stems from the recognition that the positive things you do for other people often reverberate back to create positivity in your own life. In effect, doing little things to make other people happy can greatly improve your happiness.Make sense? There are two theories at work. The first is that focusing on others creates joy of its own accord. The second is that as you succeed in improving others' happiness, you'll wind up with happier, more grateful people around you. They'll find you likable and charismatic, which in turn can lead them to treat you in a manner that produces even more happiness.It's easier said than done, but fortunately, there's a compelling shortcut. Your words are among your greatest tools, so you can have an outsize effect on others simply by thinking about what you say every day and making an effort to be both positive and sincere. There are certain inspiring things that truly happy people find themselves saying to others all the time. Try making an effort to say a few of these every day for a week. You'll be amazed at how the positivity you create improves your happiness.

Were starting a new series on the Buffer blog today with great tips and insights from Joel, CEO here at Buffer. Joel will share his ideas and insights about lifehacking, building a business and working on company culture. Here is #1:Today its a little over three years since I first had the idea for Buffer, and with the year and a half before that which I worked on my previous startup, Ive started to notice a few patterns amongst the ups and downs that come with building a startup.One of the most important things Ive learned during this time is that I perform the best when Im happy. It really does change everything. If Im happy then Im more productive when hacking code, Im better at answering support, and I find it easier to stay focused.Ive found that there are a few key habits which, for me, act as great rituals for enabling me to be consistently happy. They also act as anchor activities to bring my happiness level back up quickly whenever I have a period where Im not feeling 100%. So here are 6 of the things I do:

I had a big HIT on mechanical turk that involves predicting world events each week. When I logged in and checked the status on predictions from previous weeks, I found that two had completed that I got credit for. Finding out that my husband was coming home early made me very happy.  As a cross-country truck driver he is gone six days per week and home for 48 hours.  Many variables can have an effect on whether he returns home in a timely fashion.  Delays such as weather, mechanical problems with the truck or trailer, or delays picking up produce are sometimes frustrating for my husband.  When he takes a trip that goes well, it decreases the stress and better allows him to enjoy himself for the two days he is home with the family.

Yesterday I added a second hummingbird feeder to our yard.  Within hours our three hummingbirds became 7 or 8.  Our hummingbird family grew!  Now with two feeders you would think that the alpha bird would give up on trying to dominate who can and cannot feed from the feeders.  He is now over matched, but he doesn't realize it.  He is still acting like the all might alpha boss out there and chirping at other males that come to feed.  By having a second feeder the other males can feed while he's busy chasing off other thirsty hummingbirds.

As a nurse, I frequently bump into present and past patients in our local Walmart. Yesterday was no exception.  As I shopped I bumped into one of my favorite patients (his name is Roger) along with his son (Donny).  This gentlemen is in his 80's and has quite the comic personality.  He always wears silly hats that say something obnoxious on them.  He's always telling jokes.  Three years ago he had double bypass surgery and a subsequent stroke during recovery.  Everyone including the doctors believed he would not make it.  I went up to the ICU 45 minutes away and sat with his son for hours over the next few days.  I brought him a gift for Christmas which was a highly obnoxious dancing Christmas tree that I knew he would love.  After a few days and lots of prayers, Roger woke up miraculously!!!!  The first thing he did was tell a joke.  This family holds a special place in my heart due to their love for life even after suffering incredible losses.  Roger has suffered through the loss of his wife from cancer and his first born son from a very rare and lethal disease.  His son Donny who takes care of Roger, also suffers from the same rare disease his brother died from.  These two are wonderful people and truly an example of how not to let life let you down!

In my face, I feel a glow whenever I remember the day I went to the International trade fair with some of my friends. That was my first International trade fair visit and this was such a happy experience that I still feel a great joy reciting the memory of this event. It was January 1998 and that time I was in my first year of college.Until I finished my college, I was kind of a newborn lady, who had never visited any places without her places of her local area. After I got admitted into the college, I started exploring the world and the amazing things that invite people like us. One day I planned with my friends that we would visit International trade fair. This might seem like a very usual and banal event for others but to me, that was a really exciting thing to do. Later on, we did as we thought and finalised our visit to the fair. After break period at college, we escaped by the back door (As a side note, I would like to mention that Id no previous record of escaping school or college before). We were five in members and we hired a taxi to reach the trade fair. There wasnt enough space to sit on the back side of the taxi and the taxi driver gave a suspicious look at us. Thats why with a fishy smile we took the decision that one of us would sit in front of the baby taxi with the taxi driver. It was a funny decision but there was no alternative to us and we enjoyed it.

I would argue that these two tools, camera and video, play an integral part in different types of celebrations. First of all, most people have moments of their childhood and memories from childhood are captured in cameras. To illustrate, some of the most important events such as birthday parties, weddings, graduations and so on are included in these jigs and in this way the moment is captured and saved for a long period of time. Furthermore, as some essential and happy events are recorded, they could be used and displayed years later in order for some people to remember some significant events. A good illustration in my case is that on my 22nd birthday, my friends made me a really emotional video from all the years that we have been friends. Without the usage of the camera and video-recorder, this could never have happened.

Yesterday, our former chief minister passed away at 06:10 pm IST, now his party is counter party in the state. They requested ruling party to allocate burial ground in a particular place where his mentor already buried 50 years ago. But the ruling party has denied to give the burial space, they said there are some cases are pending against the particular place. The counter party has approached state high court at 10:30 pm to sought permission for burial ground. Today morning 08:00 am IST, arguments started between state government lawyers and counter party lawyers. Finally the Honorable Justices given permission to bury the leader in the vital place next to his mentor. His party members and public cried and enjoyed after heard the verdict. Finally he won after his death also. This is the happiest moment in tamilnadu history .The name is Kalaignar M Karunandhi - Former chief minister of Tamilnadu and President of Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam

I'm on the road for work ~250+ nights a year.  It's been over 5 years since I last spent a full week in my own bed and I've been doing this for 15 years now.  I've been dating the most wonderful woman for the past few years.  Even with my schedule and distance, she still stands by me.   At least every 24 hours we call each other, no matter the time zone differences.  I look forward to her call every morning/afternoon/evening, whenever it may be.  Because of this, my "home" is wherever the two of us are 'together', even if just by phone. So, my home is my hotel room, airport lounge, car, or anywhere the two of us are communicating. So, I received her call a few hours ago. It's nice to be home.

I have a pink flamingo neon (looks just like neon, but it's rubber & LED, non-breakable) statue I carry in my luggage when traveling.  It's become tradition that it ends up in the hotel room window when I'm in residence.  It's a little touch of Florida I drag around with me. Today, I am a completely different person. In my mind, people constantly evolve. We learn new things and meet new people, and we continue to change. For some, change is scary or un-welcomed. But for me, I love change. I love looking back and seeing how much I've grown. It's really important to me to keep learning new things, adding things to my life, and all in all, move forward. This has all led up to me becoming the strongest and happiest I've ever been...and here's why.

For starters, I have a positive mentality. Old me always dreaded everything that came my way, and if anything good happened, I started preparing for another storm. Now, my mind has completely shifted. I try to find reasoning, meaning, and the good in everything. This I think was one of the main things that turned my life around.

I also know what toxicity looks like. Now I know you can't just avoid every piece of conflict that comes headed your way, but I firmly believe that the people you surround yourself with are a reflection of who you are. They can easily rub off on you at any given time. So for me, it's very important that at any time a negative energy enters my life, that I take them out. It's very easy for me to be influenced by negativity, and I don't want to go back to that. Being able to weed out the bad seeds has become one of the best things I've ever learned.

Every night before you go to bed write three good things that happened to you that day. Jotting those down is pretty much all it takes to get a boost in well-being over time.Theres a second lesson here: the reverse is also true. Keeping track of the bad things will make you miserable. A convenient memory is a powerful thing. Do not train your brain to see the negative, teach it to see the positive.

One group was told to focus on all the upbeat things they could find sunshine, flowers, smiling pedestrians. Another was to look for negative stuff graffiti, litter, frowning faces. The third group was instructed to walk just for the exercise. At the end of the week, when the walkers well-being was tested again, those who had deliberately targeted positive cues were happier than before the experiment. The negatively focused subjects were less happy, and the just plain exercisers scored in between. The point, says Bryant, is that you see what you look for. And you can train yourself to attend to the joy out there waiting to be had, instead of passively waiting for it to come to you.
Attending a dance class made me happy, very happy actually, doing what you love gives you that natural high. I haven't been to a dance studio in a while and this is why it felt extra special.

Happiness is contagious, and our goal is to create a world with more compassion, less strife and a greater sense of purpose and meaning.
You can claim responsibility for your own happiness and become a catalyst of happiness in others lives.

That being said, I spent the day with my sister yesterday and we went to Old Navy, got lunch at Chipotle, and saw Mamma Mia at the movie theater. I hadn't been to the movies in a long time so it was nice to leave the house and see my sister. Also, it felt like everything just fell into place. For example, my sister arrived at 11:45 am. I took the puppy out to go to the bathroom, put him in his crate, and we left by 12. My husband and I took our puppy to his first puppy class yesterday. He is a very good dog and we had high expectations but he blew us away. He kept doing everything the trainer asked the first try. The trainer asked us what we were doing at home because Kodi (our puppy) was already sitting and giving paw on command. It made me happy because we hadn't really gotten validation that we were doing things right with the puppy as this is our first dog and I felt like a proud dog mom. He makes us really happy and we had gone back and forth for a long time about whether it was good timing for a puppy or not.

This morning, my puppy woke me up because he wanted to come onto the bed while my husband was getting ready for work. So I lifted him up and put him on my right side and I fell asleep again. I had an amazing breakfast this morning.  I don't usually have sit down breakfast meals, but the first scheduled meeting today was one that I simply didn't need to be at, so I had a spare hour to kill before work.  The breakfast was at a local restaurant and it was amazing.

When I did get to work, the very first meeting of the day was with a few senior execs present and we got some pretty great news.  The two projects we are running at the moment are both ahead of schedule and under budget, so we have been approved for bonus payments.  The payments will be pretty modest, but free money is money.

Until I finished my college, I was kind of a newborn lady, who had never visited any places without her places of her local area. Read something-Be it your favorite guilty-pleasure celeb gossip mag or nerding out on your favorite blog, taking a few moments to indulge in something you truly enjoy will give you a burst of positive energy. Plus you might learn something Treat yourself-Sometimes a tiny little luxury in our day is all we need to break out of a rut. Smile-In one research study subjects who smiled after a stressful activity decreased their heart rate more quickly than those who didn't. Leave a note-Make someone's day by leaving a "you're beautiful" note on the bathroom mirror.Get outside-Just a few minutes of fresh air can give you a fresh perspective.Make a statement-With your accessories. A bold statement necklace, your too-cool- for-school shades or your favorite kicks can be all you need to turn a 'blah' day around.Do something-Whether it's sending an email or clearing the clutter off your dining room table, just getting one tiny little thing off your to-do list and onto the 'it's done' list will give you a huge mental sigh of relief.

Crank the tunes. Try NOT smiling while blasting your fave feel good songStop comparing yourself. Chances are you always pick those at the very top to compare yourself to. No wonder you feel like you've come up short! Focusing on the things you've accomplished is a lot more productive.  Think positive-No matter how bad things may seem, be grateful. Warm water on a cold day? Amazing! Cold water on a warm day? Incredible! You really are very lucky when you get right down to it.

Power color-While we're partial to orange of course, whatever your favorite color is, embrace it. Bonus: when you're feeling down, treat yourself to a flower in your fave color. It will brighten the room and your outlook. Stop comparing yourself-Chances are you always pick those at the very top to compare yourself to. No wonder you feel like you've come up short! I became a proud father of a baby boy and the boy is a surprise for me. When my wife was diagnosed as pregnant, she had to undergo different tests advised from the doctor. The doctor, a gynaecologist, advised for an ultrasonogram and the report was positive for her. The report said that she was carrying a baby girl. I was happy with the news and shared it with my family members and friends. My wife was also happy with the news of a baby girl. She, in fact, started the preparation for the baby girl. She took me to shopping for the girl and bought some small dresses for a newborn baby girl. She also bought some dolls and toys for our baby. Days were passing amid great excitement that we are going to be parents for the first time in our life. Our near and dear ones also congratulated us for the good news. In fact, it was impossible for both of us to wait any longer for the baby. We were counting days. But when the baby came into the material world, it surprised us all.

I was able to prank my care giver when she got here. I am normally in my chair at the computer when she arrives but I was in my extra bedroom looking for something and heard her come in. I quietly shut the door most of the way and heard her calling out my name as she was looking through the house for me. She passed the room I was in thinking I wouldn't be in there and continued on to my bedroom. I opened up the door, disguised my voice, and said "peekie booie" and she let out a screech, jumped up and down exclaiming "Oh, Miss! You about scared the life out of me!" We were both laughing so hard we were out of breath. We are always pranking each other and having a good time.

My care giver and I watched a You Tube video of a surgical proceedure showing a simular surgery to what my sister recently had done. My care giver was all intense and really getting "into" the proceedure and I was "eweing" every cut that was being made. She started laughing at me and I was laughing at her. Between the two of us the patient probably would have died on the table because we would be "cutting up" so badly. I guess we are best left to be You Tube surgeons for the greater good of humanity.

In the first place, marriage is intended to provide security, both financial and emotional. Of the two types, emotional security is of greater importance to the integrity of the home. It is the natural craving for emotional security that impels young men and women toward marriage. Many a single person would prefer to avoid the obligations and responsibilities implied in marriage were it not for a realization of the need of emotional security that comes from being able to confide in a husband or a wife and expect this partner to be partial and unprejudiced, as he or she shares the problems and anxieties of the moment. The competitions of life are too strong and the jealousies too caustic to make it feasible or desirable to face life alone. Marriage provides a complementary self which serves as an emotional counter-balance.

Host a themed event with Casino style gaming. Poker tables, card games, roulette, and more will make this event special. You can raise money in a few different ways. Some fundraising ideas for Casino nights include having a bar and charging for drinks, charging admission to attend the event, charging guests for the chips that they will use to play the various games. You can also host a raffle at the event and sell tickets for that in addition to any of the other fundraising ideas. This type of event does require planning and manpower, so if you would rather do something more effortless, consider some other fundraising ideas.

Jotting those down is pretty much all it takes to get a boost in well-being over time.Theres a second lesson here: the reverse is also true. Keeping track of the bad things will make you miserable. Before you start planning your ceremony order, know this: No two wedding ceremonies are alike. Even if some couples say the same vows or take a deep dip for the kiss, every pair has a unique mix of things as it comes to their officiant, remarks, ring exchanges, recessional and more. That said, the below is a traditional wedding ceremony order of events to guide your preferences, but don't feel like you need to include every step or stick to a certain time frame.
Basically the reverse of the processional, you exit the ceremony together as newlyweds, followed by the wedding party.

Isolating yourself from social contact is a pretty common response to feeling unhappy, but theres a large body of research that says its the worst thing you can do. This is a huge mistake, as socializing, even when you dont enjoy it, is great for your mood.

We need to feel in control of our lives in order to be happy, which is why blaming is so incompatible with happiness. When you blame other people or circumstances for the bad things that happen to you, youve decided that you have no control over your life, which is terrible for your mood.
